card.title: Introduction to Linear Equations
card.content: A linear equation is a mathematical equation that describes a straight line when graphed. It has the general form y = mx + b, where m is the slope and b is the y-intercept.

card.title: Types of Linear Equations
card.content: There are three main forms: Standard Form (Ax + By = C), Slope-intercept Form (y = mx + b), and Point-slope Form (y - y₁ = m(x - x₁)).

card.title: Solving Linear Equations
card.content: To solve a linear equation, isolate the variable by performing inverse operations on both sides of the equation. Always maintain equality by doing the same operation to both sides.

card.title: Graphing Linear Equations
card.content: Linear equations graph as straight lines. The slope determines steepness and direction, while the y-intercept shows where the line crosses the y-axis.

card.title: Applications
card.content: Linear equations are used in real-world scenarios like calculating costs, distance-time relationships, and business profit models.

card.title: What are Quadratic Equations?
card.content: A quadratic equation is a polynomial equation of degree 2, with the standard form ax² + bx + c = 0, where a ≠ 0.

card.title: The Quadratic Formula
card.content: The quadratic formula x = (-b ± √(b² - 4ac)) / 2a can solve any quadratic equation. The discriminant (b² - 4ac) determines the nature of roots.

card.title: Factoring Method
card.content: Many quadratic equations can be solved by factoring into two binomials. Find two numbers that multiply to 'ac' and add to 'b'.

card.title: Completing the Square
card.content: This method involves creating a perfect square trinomial by adding and subtracting the same value to complete the square.

card.title: Graphing Parabolas
card.content: Quadratic equations graph as parabolas. The vertex form y = a(x - h)² + k shows the vertex at (h, k) and whether the parabola opens up or down.

card.title: Types of Triangles
card.content: Triangles can be classified by sides: Equilateral (all sides equal), Isosceles (two sides equal), and Scalene (all sides different).

card.title: Triangle Angles
card.content: The sum of interior angles in any triangle is always 180°. Triangles can also be classified by angles: Acute, Right, and Obtuse.

card.title: Pythagorean Theorem
card.content: In a right triangle, a² + b² = c², where c is the hypotenuse and a, b are the other two sides. This fundamental theorem has countless applications.

card.title: Triangle Congruence
card.content: Triangles are congruent if they have the same shape and size. Congruence can be proven using SSS, SAS, ASA, AAS, or HL postulates.

card.title: Triangle Similarity
card.content: Similar triangles have the same shape but different sizes. Their corresponding angles are equal and corresponding sides are proportional.

card.title: Types of Motion
card.content: Motion can be linear (straight line), rotational (around an axis), oscillatory (back and forth), or random (unpredictable path).

card.title: Distance vs Displacement
card.content: Distance is the total path traveled (scalar), while displacement is the straight-line distance from start to end point (vector).

card.title: Speed vs Velocity
card.content: Speed is distance traveled per unit time (scalar), while velocity is displacement per unit time (vector) and includes direction.

card.title: Acceleration
card.content: Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity. It can be positive (speeding up), negative (slowing down), or zero (constant velocity).

card.title: Equations of Motion
card.content: The three kinematic equations relate displacement, velocity, acceleration, and time: v = u + at, s = ut + ½at², and v² = u² + 2as.

card.title: Newton's First Law
card.content: An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion at constant velocity, unless acted upon by an unbalanced force.

card.title: Newton's Second Law
card.content: The acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass: F = ma.

card.title: Newton's Third Law
card.content: For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. Forces always occur in pairs acting on different objects.

card.title: Types of Forces
card.content: Common forces include gravitational, normal, friction, tension, applied, and elastic forces. Each has unique characteristics and applications.

card.title: Free Body Diagrams
card.content: Free body diagrams show all forces acting on an object. They help analyze motion and solve force problems systematically.

card.title: Structure of an Atom
card.content: An atom consists of a nucleus (containing protons and neutrons) surrounded by electrons in energy levels or shells.

card.title: Subatomic Particles
card.content: Protons have positive charge, electrons have negative charge, and neutrons are neutral. Protons and neutrons have nearly equal mass, much greater than electrons.

card.title: Atomic Number and Mass
card.content: Atomic number equals the number of protons and defines the element. Atomic mass is the average mass of all isotopes of an element.

card.title: Electron Configuration
card.content: Electrons occupy specific energy levels and subshells (s, p, d, f) following the aufbau principle, Pauli exclusion principle, and Hund's rule.

card.title: Isotopes
card.content: Isotopes are atoms of the same element with different numbers of neutrons. They have identical chemical properties but different physical properties.

card.title: Cell Theory
card.content: All living things are made of cells, the cell is the basic unit of life, and all cells come from pre-existing cells.

card.title: Prokaryotic vs Eukaryotic
card.content: Prokaryotic cells lack a membrane-bound nucleus (bacteria), while eukaryotic cells have a nucleus and organelles (plants, animals, fungi).

card.title: Cell Membrane
card.content: The cell membrane is a phospholipid bilayer that controls what enters and exits the cell through selective permeability.

card.title: Organelles
card.content: Key organelles include nucleus (control center), mitochondria (powerhouse), endoplasmic reticulum (transport), and Golgi apparatus (packaging).

card.title: Cell Transport
card.content: Materials move across membranes by passive transport (diffusion, osmosis) or active transport (requiring energy to move against gradients).

card.title: Nouns
card.content: Nouns are words that name persons, places, things, or ideas. They can be common or proper, concrete or abstract, countable or uncountable.

card.title: Pronouns
card.content: Pronouns replace nouns to avoid repetition. Types include personal, possessive, reflexive, demonstrative, interrogative, and relative pronouns.

card.title: Verbs
card.content: Verbs express actions, states, or occurrences. They can be main verbs, auxiliary verbs, or modal verbs, and change form for tense, mood, and voice.

card.title: Adjectives
card.content: Adjectives describe or modify nouns and pronouns. They can show quality, size, age, color, origin, material, or purpose.

card.title: Adverbs
card.content: Adverbs modify verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs. They often answer how, when, where, or to what extent something happens.

card.title: Geography and the Nile
card.content: Ancient Egypt developed along the Nile River, which provided water, fertile soil, and transportation. The predictable flooding cycle enabled agriculture.

card.title: Pharaohs and Government
card.content: Egypt was ruled by pharaohs who were considered divine. The government was highly centralized with a complex bureaucracy of officials and scribes.

card.title: Pyramids and Architecture
card.content: Egyptians built magnificent pyramids as tombs for pharaohs. These structures demonstrate advanced engineering and mathematical knowledge.

card.title: Religion and Afterlife
card.content: Egyptians believed in many gods and goddesses and had elaborate beliefs about the afterlife, leading to mummification and tomb construction.

card.title: Hieroglyphics
card.content: Egyptian writing system using pictures and symbols. The Rosetta Stone was key to deciphering hieroglyphics in modern times.
